Section Navigation

  • spyctra

spyctra#

The methods below are designed to be terse. One common convention is that methods will accept a single value and then apply it to all spyctra within self, and they can accept an iterable, with length equal to self.count, with each value applied to the corresponding spyctra.

spyctra.__init__(self, path=None, **kwargs)#

Initialize the spyctra object.

Parameters:

  • path (str or None) – Optional path to a previously saved spyctra.

  • data (list[ndarray]) – List of ndarrays containing the individual spyctra data.

  • start (float) – The initial x-axis value.

  • delta (float) – The x-axis increment.

  • space (str) – A flag indicating if the data is in the time (‘s’) or frequency (‘Hz’) domain. Default is ‘s’.

  • phi (ndarray or None) – The cumulative phase adjustments made to each spyctra. Default is 0.

  • meta (dict or None) – A dictionary of iterables that track additional metadata of the spyctra.

  • freq (ndarray or None) – The observation frequencies of the spyctra. Default is 0.

  • time (ndarray[float/datetime.timestamp]) – The datetime.timestamps of the spyctra (i.e. seconds since Jan 1, 1970). Default it 0.

spyctra.__getitem__(self, ind)#

Copy individual spyctra into a new object in a pythonic way.

Parameters:

ind (int or list[int] or slice) – The spyctra in self to copy.

Returns:

A new spyctra that is a subset of the original.

Return type:

spyctra

spyctra.count(self)#

Return the number of spyctra i.e. len(self.data).

Returns:

len(self.data).

Return type:

int

spyctra.points(self)#

Return the length of the spyctra. Spyctra assumes, but does not require, self.data[i] all have the same length.

Returns:

len(self.data[0]).

Return type:

int

spyctra.x(self)#

Return the x-axis of the data using self.start and self.delta. More efficient than always storing the whole thing since self.start and self.delta are generally more useful.

Returns:

The x-axis of the data.

Return type:

ndarray

spyctra.add(self, new_spyctra)#

Add additional spyctra to self.

Parameters:

new_spyctra (spyctra) – The spyctra to add to self.

spyctra.copy(self, *user_copy, quiet=0)#

Copy the selected spyctra.

Parameters:

  • user_copy (int or iterable[int] or None) – The spyctra to copy. Default is all, i.e. self.count.

  • quiet – A flag that suppresses output during copy.

Returns:

A new spyctra object.

Return type:

spyctra

spyctra.decimate(self, number=0)#

Average self.data at each x value across number of spyctra.

Parameters:

number (int) – The number of spyctra to average. If self.count%number > 0, decimate will ignore the remainder. Default behavior (i.e. number == 0), will decimate by self.count.

spyctra.exp_mult(self, FWHM)#

Weight the spyctra by an exponential decay with time constant 1/pi/FWHM. Doesn’t check for time domain because spyctra lets you do you.

Parameters:

FWHM (float or iterable[float]) – The FWHM used to define the time constants of the exponential weighting.

spyctra.fft(self, divide=0, rezero=1)#

FFT data from time to frequency domain or vice versa based on self.space.

Parameters:

  • divide (int[0, 1]) – If divide == 1 divides first point in half when going to frequency domain and corrects when going back to the time domain. Historical feature from v0 of spyctra and Originlab NMR Tools.

  • rezero (int[0, 1]) – If rezero == 1 performs fftshift on the FFTed data. Appropriate for demodulated data.

spyctra.get_df(self)#

Estimate the off-resonance (delta-f) of the peak, relative to the observation frequency, of the spyctra data in the frequency domain.

Returns:

The array of off-resonances.

Return type:

ndarray[float]

spyctra.get_freq(self)#

Estimate the absolute frequency of the peak of the spyctra data in the frequency domain.

Returns:

The array of frequencies for each element in self.data.

Return type:

ndarray[float]

spyctra.get_lw(self, component='R')#

Estimate the full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the signal in the frequency domain by 1) finding the index of the peak of the signal, 2) finding the left and right indices where the signal is less than half of the peak value.

Parameters:

component (char or None) – Which component (RIM) of the spyctra to use to calculate the linewidth.

Returns:

The array of FWHM, in Hz, for each spyctra.

Return type:

ndarray[float].

spyctra.get_noise(self, fraction=4)#

Estimate the RMS of the magnitude of noise in the frequency domain using the first and last 1/fraction of the data.

Parameters:

fraction (int) – The fraction of data, on both the left and right of the spyctra, that is sampled to calculate the RMS noise.

Returns:

The array of the RMS of the noise for each spyctra.

Return type:

ndarray[float].

spyctra.get_offset(self, fraction=8)#

Estimate the DC offset of each spyctra by averaging the last 1/fraction of the data.

Parameters:

fraction (int) – The fraction of data sampled to calculate the offset.

Returns:

The array of the offsets for each spyctra.

Return type:

ndarray[float, complex].

spyctra.get_peak(self, component='M')#

Return the index and value of the peak of the signal for the specified component.

Parameters:

component (char) – Which component (RIM) of the spyctra to process.

Returns:

A list of two ndarrays containing the indices and values corresponding to the peak.

Return type:

list[ndarray[int], ndarray[float, complex]]

spyctra.get_phi(self)#

Calculate the phase adjustment needed to phase the data to the peak.

Returns:

List of phases in radians.

Return type:

ndarray[float]

spyctra.get_phi_by_time(self)#

Calculate the phase of each point for each spyctra. Useful for identifying electromagnet instabilities.

Returns:

ndarray of ndarrays of the phase for each spyctra.

Return type:

ndarray[ndarray[float]]

spyctra.get_point(self, x_indices, component='C')#

Return the specified component of the value at the specified point[s].

Parameters:

  • x_indices – The specific index returned from each spyctra.

  • component (char) – The component (RIMC) of the value to return.

Returns:

The desired values list.

Return type:

ndarray[float, complex]

spyctra.get_snr(self, peaks=None)#

Return the signal to noise ratio (SNR) at the peak signal location (default) or user specified location. Noise is always the default self.noise calculation.

Parameters:

peaks (int or iterable[int] or None) – Where to calculate the signal. If peaks == None uses the absolute peak of the data.

Returns:

The SNR[s].

Return type:

ndarray[float]

spyctra.get_time(self, t0=None, scale=1)#

Calculate the time since t0 for each spyctra and then divide by scale to put into desired units.

Parameters:

  • t0 (float/datetime.timestamp or None) – The initial time to compare to. If t0 == None will use time of first spyctra.

  • scale (float) – The number of seconds to divide the elapsed times by to convert to minutes (60), hours(60*60), days(24*60*60), etc.

Returns:

The elapsed times.

Return type:

ndarray[float]

spyctra.imshow(self, *args)#

Plot a 2d representation of the desired subset of self.data.

Parameters:

  • to_plot (int or iterable[float]) – Subset of spyctra to plot. Default is all.

  • component (char or str) – Which component[s] (RIM) of the data to plot. Default is ‘M’.

spyctra.integrate(self, components='R')#

Return results of trapezoidal integration of the spyctra by the specified component[s].

Parameters:

components (char or str or None) – Which components (RIM) to integrate. Default is ‘R’.

Returns:

The desired integrals.

Return type:

ndarray[float] or ndarray[ndarray[float]]

spyctra.new_count(self, N)#

Refactor the data into N new spyctra. If N > self.count, metadata such as self.freq is preserved. If N < self.count, metadata is lost.

Parameters:

N (int) – The number of new spyctra to create from the existing data.

spyctra.normalize(self, norm=None)#

Divide spyctra by the specified value[s]. Default is to normalize by the largest value in each spyctra.

Parameters:

norm (float or iterable[float]) – The value used to divide each spyctra.

spyctra.open(self, path)#

Open a pickled spyctra object.

Parameters:

path (str) – The path to the pickled spyctra.

spyctra.phase(self, phis=None)#

Phase spyctra by the specified value[s] in phis.

Parameters:

phis (float or iterable[float]) – The phase adjustment, in radians, to be made to each spyctra. Default is to use the values return by self.get_phi.

spyctra.phase_foc(self, phase_corrs)#

Apply first or phase correction[s].

Parameters:

phase_corrs (iterable[iterable[dPhidF, f0, phi0]]) – The phase adjustment to be made to each spyctra.

spyctra.plot(self, *args)#

Plot the desired subset of spyctra as adjacent plots.

Parameters:

  • to_plot (int or iterable[int]) – The subset of spyctra to plot. Default is all spyctra.

  • component (char or str) – Which components (RIM) of the data to plot. Default is ‘RIM’.

spyctra.plot_over(self, *args)#

Plot the desired subset of spyctra overlaid in a single figure.

Parameters:

  • to_plot (int or iterable[int]) – The subset of spyctra to plot. Default is all spyctra.

  • component (char or str) – Which components (RIM) of the data to plot. Default is ‘RIM’.

spyctra.plot_phase_corr(self, dPhidF=0, dPhidF_inc=0.001, f0=0, f0_inc=0.01, phi0=0, phi0_inc=0.1)#

Open the interactive first order phase correction GUI and return the results.

Parameters:

  • dPhidF (float) – The rate of change of phase with respect to frequency in units of phase per Hz.

  • dPhidF_inc (float) – The scale for the slider on the GUI for dPhidF.

  • f0 (float) – The center frequency for the first order correction in units of Hz.

  • f0_inc (float) – The scale for the slider on the GUI for f0.

  • phi0 (float) – The zeroth order phase correction in units of radians.

  • dphi0_inc (float) – The scale for the slider on the GUI for dphi0.

spyctra.pop(self, to_remove)#

Remove the specified spyctra from self.

Parameters:

to_remove (int or iterable[int]) – The subset of spyctra to remove.

spyctra.print(self, points=None)#

Print spyctra data*[:*points] to standard output.

Parameters:

points (int) – The number of points to print.

spyctra.report(self)#

Print useful information about the spyctra.

spyctra.resize(self, N)#

Resize spyctra by removing data or adding zeros. If N is an integer, truncate or append zeros to make self.points == N. If N is negative, N zeros are prepended. If N is list, isolate data between the extremes in the list.

Parameters:

N (int or iterable) – The new length of the spyctra.

Returns:

The indices used to subset the data if N is a list.

Return type:

list

spyctra.save(self, path)#

Pickle a spyctra and save to path for future processing.

Parameters:

path (str) – The path to save the pickled spyctra.

spyctra.shift(self, shifts)#

Remove the first shift points or add shift zeros to the spyctra data.

Parameters:

shifts (int or iterable[int]) – If shifts > 0 then remove those points and append zeros. If shifts < 0 prepend shift zeros.

spyctra.smooth(self, smooth)#

Successivle average points within a spyctra. Effectively a computationally cheap low-pass filter.

Parameters:

smooth (int) – the number of adjacent points to average. If smooth%self.points > 0 the remainder of points will be dropped.

spyctra.sort(self, x)#

Sort the spyctra by the keys of the iterable x. Sort all relevant parts of self: data, freq, phi, meta, time.

Parameters:

x (iterable) – The iterable used to identify how to sort the parts of self. len(x) must equal self.count.

spyctra.subtract(self, offset)#

Subtract offset[s] from the spyctra.

Parameters:

offset (float(complex), iterable(float, complex)) – The offset[s] to subtract from each spyctra.

spyctra.transpose(self)#

Transpose the data in self. Resets self: freq, time, meta, phi.

fake_spyctra(points=1024, delta=10e-6, df=0, noise=0, t_2=numpy.inf, phi=0, seed=None, amp=512, scans=1, freq=0, meta={}):

A quick way to generate spyctra. Will even simulate digitization of the data. This is a powerful way to test methods and can even be used for improved spectral analysis of actual data in conjunction with fitlib. Assumes data will have the form of a complex exponential decay.

Parameters:

  • points (int) – The length of the spyctra data.

  • delta (int or list) – The x increment of the spyctra x-axis.

  • df (float) – The off-resonance (delta-f) of the spyctra compared to the observation frequency freq.

  • noise (float) – The standard deviation of the noise in both the real and imaginary channels from one scan.

  • t_2 (float) – The decay constant, in seconds, of the data.

  • phi (float) – The phase offset, in radians, of the data.

  • seed (None or int) – A random seed to obtain distinct noise between spyctra. Default is to use the system time.

  • amp (float) – The initial amplitude of the data.

  • scans (int) – Simulates averaged data by holding amp constant and reducing noise by scans**0.5.

  • freq (float) – The observation frequency of the data. Default is 0.

  • meta (dict) – A dictionary for other information about the spyctra.

Returns:

The fake spyctra.

Return type:

spyctra
